body:
This is still an error with 0.12.0. Here's some standalone code:

```python
from sktime.transformations.series.date import DateTimeFeatures
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.compose import ForecastingPipeline
from sktime.transformations.hierarchical.aggregate import Aggregator
from sktime.transformations.hierarchical.reconcile import Reconciler

from sktime.utils._testing.hierarchical import _make_hierarchical

y_train_hier = _make_hierarchical()
X_train_hier = _make_hierarchical()

FH = [1, 2]

steps=[
        ("daily_season", DateTimeFeatures(ts_freq="D")),  
        ("daily_season2", DateTimeFeatures(manual_selection=["week_of_month", "day_of_quarter"])),
]  

forecaster_hier = NaiveForecaster()

# Version 1A: Local Vectorized (Hierarchical) Forecasts (without reconciliation)
pipe_hier_norecon = ForecastingPipeline(steps= steps + [("forecaster", forecaster_hier)])

# Version 1B: Local Vectorized (Hierarchical) Forecasts (with reconciliation)
pipe_hier_recon = Aggregator() * pipe_hier_norecon * Reconciler(method="ols")

# Version 1A: Local Vectorized (Hierarchical) Forecasts (without reconciliation)
# This works
_ = pipe_hier_norecon.fit(y_train_hier, X_train_hier, fh=FH)

# Version 1B: Local Vectorized (Hierarchical) Forecasts (with reconciliation)
# Does not work with X_train (is it because of empty X dataframe?)
# If 1A works with X_train, shouldn't 1B also work?
_ = pipe_hier_recon.fit(y_train_hier, X_train_hier, fh=FH)

# This works (without passing X)
# _ = pipe_hier_recon.fit(y_train_hier, fh=FH)
```
@ciaran-g, it would be kind if you could have a look at this. Seems to be coming from the reconciler?

issue.title: [BUG] loosen index check related tags and fix incorrect pipeline tag inference

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR loosens checks related to index equality related tags:

* if a forecaster has `"X-y-must-have-same-index"` and `"ignores-exogeneous-X"` tag both set to True, this will no longer result in an exception if `X` is passed and is not index compliant with `y`. Why: if `X` is ignored, then `X.index` should also not matter for anything, including checks.
* In transformer and forecaster pipelines, the `"X-y-must-have-same-index"` tag is no longer copied from forecaster or conjunction-inferred from transformers. This was logically incorrect, as there are transformers that can add or remove indices. There have been actual instances of unexpected behaviour around this in pipelines. Example 1: `Aggregator` which adds indices https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2711; example 2: `Differencer` which removes indices https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2807, https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2452
(FYI @ngupta23, @anthonygiorgio97)
* if a forecaster has `"ignores-exogeneous-X"`, then `X=None` is passed to the inner methods, instead of performing unnecessary conversions on `X` and passing the result to the inner methods. This is done after performing input checks on `X`, to let the user know early of non-conformant `X` - even if `X` is never used.

The PR also adds two tests that ensure that the ablated examples from https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2711 run.

body: FYI @ciaran-g, @ngupta23, #2842 should address part of this.

issue.title: [BUG] Vectorization in transformers overwrote y with X

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Thie fixes the following unreported bug related to https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2841 and https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2711:

when a transformer entered vectorization mode and `y` was passed (and also vectorized), then the transformer would pass the vectorized `X` to the inner methods where a vectorized `y` should have passed, i.e., passing `X` as `X` (correctly), and `y` as `X` as well (incorrectly). This has been fixed.

(was difficult to spot since the condition is a rare combination of (a) a transformer uses `y` at all, and (b) vectorization happens)

Relation to the bugs:
* after the type inference bug in #2841 is fixed, the test example posted by me breaks due to this unreported bug
* in #2711, it seem like `X` in the forecaster is not properly aggregated. There is not a clear causal link, and the vectorization in forecasters seem correct. Still there is something going on that seems similar, so I reference it.

body:
So, further investigated this today with @ciaran-g.

The reason seems that the pipeline, as constructed by @ngupta23 creates the extra hierarchical indices in `y` before it creates them in `X`, by running the transformed target pipeline (the one acting on `y`) on the outside, this before, of the pipeline acting on `X`.

This ablated, minimal example breaks:

```python
from sktime.transformations.hierarchical.aggregate import Aggregator
from sktime.forecasting.arima import ARIMA
from sktime.forecasting.compose import ForecastingPipeline
from sktime.datatypes import get_examples
from sktime.datatypes._utilities import get_window

X = get_examples("pd_multiindex_hier")[0]
y = get_examples("pd_multiindex_hier")[1]

X_train = get_window(X, lag=1)
y_train = get_window(y, lag=1)
X_test = get_window(X, window_length=1)

f = Aggregator() * ForecastingPipeline([Aggregator(), ARIMA()])

f.fit(y=y_train, X=X_train, fh=1)
f.predict(X=X_test)
```

Doing it the other way round, however, works:

```python
from sktime.transformations.hierarchical.aggregate import Aggregator
from sktime.forecasting.arima import ARIMA
from sktime.forecasting.compose import ForecastingPipeline
from sktime.datatypes import get_examples
from sktime.datatypes._utilities import get_window

X = get_examples("pd_multiindex_hier")[0]
y = get_examples("pd_multiindex_hier")[1]

X_train = get_window(X, lag=1)
y_train = get_window(y, lag=1)
X_test = get_window(X, window_length=1)

f = ForecastingPipeline([Aggregator(), Aggregator() * ARIMA()])

f.fit(y=y_train, X=X_train, fh=1)
f.predict(X=X_test)
```

While logical if one explains it, both of us immediately understood how this can lead to user frustration - especially since we also didn't understand it right away!

PR https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2842 which relaxes the index compatibiltiy checks and does not carry them out right away (but only in the components) should prevent any future instances of this. On the PR branch, both examples work as expected.

FYI @ngupta23. Took a bit long to hunt this down, sorry.

@fkiraly just confirming that the code you pasted there works for me! I think there is still something else to fix here though, because if you replace the `AIRMA()` with the `NaiveForecaster()` which should ignore `X_train`, then fitting the pipeline still raises an error on the #2842 PR branch.

Will update here later after some digging (:
